I have uploaded a PR #16584 that does various things in this direction:

  • Define monomial orders
  • Prove the division algorithm for a given monomial order (it works in a ring, the only condition is that the leading coefficient of each polynomial to divide by is a unit)
  • Define the 4 standard monomial orders (lexicographic, reverse lexicographic, and the two other one that first consider degrees)
  • A section (no more used) about Dickson orders, a stronger version of WellFounded which is traditionally used in that area, is somewhat easier to prove, but less general

I need comments on various points :

  • What about my definition of a structure MonomialOrder? The point is it has to encapsulate an docs#AddEquiv to a type that contains the correct order. It would be simpler to just invoke the correct ordering relation, but then I can't use stuff such as docs#Finset.sup
  • Presumably, the four parts need to be split into 4 files (not saying about 4 PRs)
This PR is used to replace the ad hoc division method in #16177 which formalizes the proof of Alon's Combinatorial Nullstellensatz.

This PR has a lot of nice and small API lemmas. I am hopeful that this theory might go through quickly.

  • I don't know of a better way to support these multiple orders. Your approach makes a lot of sense.
  • There is a bunch of dead code in this PR. Could you please create a version that is "minimalistic" and only contains stuff that you need for #16177. (Other stuff could be added later in follow up PRs.)
  • As you indicate, this new PR could also split things into multiple files.

I noticed (especially for #16177) that the m.toSyn approach has some drawback when one works with specific order because it hides the adequate function (toDegLex, for example) and forces to use change before one can unfold the specific definition of the chosen monomial ordering.
Could a helper lemma be used with rw to expose this, instead of change?
I'll try that. The other possibility would be to work in the type definition, but I don't know.
